title: Isolation and immunofluorescence staining of Aspergillus fumigatus conidia-containing phagolysosomes
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of A. fumigatus conidia and macrophage cell line (RAW264.7)
For the isolation of phagolysosomes from macrophages seeding of a defined amount of macrophages in well plates and cultivation of A. fumigatus conidia until sporulation is necessary and described below.
Timing: 10 min
Revival of A. fumigatus conidia from cryopreservation
Use an inoculation loop to spread conidia on a petri dish with Aspergillus Minimal Medium agar (Pontecorvo et al., 1953[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3])
Incubate conidia-plated agar plate for 5 days at 37°C
Timing: 30 min plus 3 days
Seed macrophage cell line
Preheat cell culture medium (see “Materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]”), which should be stored at 4°C, to 37°C in a water bath
Prepare 2 × 25 cm2 cell culture flasks with 3 × 105 macrophages (revived from cryopreserved cell line) and 7 mL culture medium each
Incubate flasks for 3 days at 37°C and 5% (v/v) CO2
Timing: 1 h plus 1 day
Harvest conidia 5 days after mycelial growth and sporulation on agar plates
Slowly add 10 mL 0.9% (w/v) NaCl, 0.01% (v/v) Tween 20 solution to the petri dish
Use a T-formed spatula to scrap the conidia
Measure concentration of conidia by using a 1:100 dilution and counting with a Thoma chamber or another counting method
Harvest adherent macrophages with a confluency of 80%–90%
Pre-warm culture medium to 37°C in water bath
Remove the old medium from macrophages’ culture flask by aspiration
Add 3 mL of fresh pre-warmed medium
Use a cell scraper to scrape the macrophages from the base of the culture flask
Collect cell suspension in a 15 mL Falcon tube
Measure cell concentration by Thoma chamber or another counting system
Seed cells for infection with A. fumigatus conidia

Add 5 mL medium + 4 × 106 macrophages to each well of a 4-well plate (21,8 cm2/well)
Incubate cells 24 h at 37°C and 5% (v/v) CO2
Infection of macrophages with A. fumigatus conidia
Macrophages are incubated with a defined amount of conidia to allow phagocytosis and formation of a conidia-containing phagolysosome. The implementation of infection is explained in the following.
Timing: 3 h
Replace culture medium of the 4-well plate containing macrophages
Remove the old medium
Add 3 mL pre-warmed fresh medium to the cells
Phagocytosis of A. fumigatus conidia by macrophages
Infect macrophages using an MOI of 5; incubate for 30 min at 4°C to synchronize phagocytosis
Allow phagocytosis for 2 h at 37°C and 5% (v/v) CO2
Isolation of conidia-containing phagolysosomes
Formed phagolysosomes are isolated by the described cell lysis and Biocoll-separating process.
Timing: 3 h
Isolation of infected cells from plate
Pre-cool a tabletop centrifuge to 4°C
Remove old medium of the 4 wells of the infected macrophages by aspiration
Wash cells by adding 3 mL PBS per well and remove PBS
Harvest cells with cell scraper in 1.5 mL PBS per well
From each well, transfer cell suspension to a separate 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube
Centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min at 4°C
Homogenization of cells
Discard supernatant
Resuspend cell pellet in 1 mL homogenization buffer (250 mM sucrose, 3 mM imidazole, pH 7.4) containing protease inhibitors
Lyse cells on ice by passing the cell suspensions 20 times per pellet through a 26G needle on a 1 mL syringe
Critical: Slowly pass the cell suspension through a needle to avoid air bubbles in the tube. Passing times should not fall below 20 times to improve cell lysis.
Check cell breakage
Add 5 μL trypan blue to 5 μL cell suspension

Microscopic observation shows blue staining, which indicates disrupted cell membranes
Release of actin/myosin interaction
Incubate each cell homogenate with 300 μL of 10 mM ATP for 15 min with rotation at 4°C
Separation of phagolysosomes from cell debris
Split the 1 mL homogenate into portions of 500 μL; carefully overlay each 500 μL on top of 500 μL Biocoll (1.077 g/mL) in a reaction tube by using a 200 μL tip
Critical: A small pipette tip avoids too fast layering of the homogenate onto Biocoll and improves separating process.
Centrifuge at 600 × g for 20 min at 4°C
Discard supernatant
Wash pelleted conidia-containing phagolysosomes twice with ice-cold 500 μL PBS with centrifugation in-between for 5 min, 600 × g, at 4°C
Resuspend pellet in 150 μL ice-cold PBS and collect all samples in one tube
Seed 20 μL suspension + 1 mL PBS or count phagolysosomes and place a certain amount on a coverslip in a 24-well plate and store at 4°C (possible for max. 1 day) to allow the phagolysosomes to attach onto the coverslip. Alternatively, isolated phagolysosomes can be lysed for Western Blot analysis.
Immunofluorescence staining of conidia-containing phagolysosomes
Timing: 6 h
Membrane-associated targets of isolated phagolysosomes can be stained with specific antibodies using immunofluorescence technology as described below.
Fixation of phagolysosomes
Slowly remove PBS from each well
Add 350 μL methanol/acetone (80%/20% (v/v)) or 3.5% (v/v) formaldehyde/PBS or 4% PFA for 15 min RT (depending on the target)
Wash three times with 350 μL PBS
Blocking and staining
Remove PBS
Add 350 μL 2% (w/v) BSA/PBS for 1 h
Remove blocking solution
Add 300 μL primary antibody diluted in blocking solutions as recommended for 1.5 h
Wash three times with PBS for 30 s
Remove PBS

Add 300 μL secondary antibody diluted in blocking solutions as recommended for 1 h
Wash three times with PBS for 30 s
Mount coverslips on a glass slide with mounting medium
